anchor.surface_text: When it was deposited with the Central Government it was a portion of the profits of the business of the assessee and when it was returned to the assessee it must be restored to its character of being a part of the profits of a business. It cannot be said that its nature changes merely because it is refunded as a cons

It would, thus appear that the amount of excess profits tax was an allowable deduction for the purpose of companyputation of the business profits of an, assessee under s. 12 1  of the Excess Profits Tax Act and when it or a portion of it wag refunded it had to be treated as income of the assessee. When it was deposited with the Central Government it was a portion of the profits of the business of the assessee and when it was returned to the assessee it must be restored to its character of being a part of the profits of a business.

It would, thus appear that the amount of excess profits tax was an allowable deduction for the purpose of companyputation of the business profits of an, assessee under s. 12 1  of the Excess Profits Tax Act and when it or a portion of it wag refunded it had to be treated as income of the assessee. When it was deposited with the Central Government it was a portion of the profits of the business of the assessee and when it was returned to the assessee it must be restored to its character of being a part of the profits of a business.

It would, thus appear that the amount of excess profits tax was an allowable deduction for the purpose of companyputation of the business profits of an, assessee under s. 12 1  of the Excess Profits Tax Act and when it or a portion of it wag refunded it had to be treated as income of the assessee. When it was deposited with the Central Government it was a portion of the profits of the business of the assessee and when it was returned to the assessee it must be restored to its character of being a part of the profits of a business.

It would, thus appear that the amount of excess profits tax was an allowable deduction for the purpose of companyputation of the business profits of an, assessee under s. 12 1  of the Excess Profits Tax Act and when it or a portion of it wag refunded it had to be treated as income of the assessee. When it was deposited with the Central Government it was a portion of the profits of the business of the assessee and when it was returned to the assessee it must be restored to its character of being a part of the profits of a business.
